Anyway, thanks for playing! I can't wait to check out what the rest of you guys made.

entries.title: Magno-Warrior
entries.description:
A top-down shoot-'em-up where your only weapons are the enemies themselves.
Controls are WASD to move, and mouse to rotate your ship.
When an enemy runs out of health, it becomes "deactivated". This allows you to attach it to your ship by touching it. When it is attached to your ship, it will begin firing again, harming enemies instead of you!
If all of the ships attached to yours are destroyed, leaving you defenseless, you can ram your ship into an active enemy ship. It will cost you one life point, but it will attach to you.

There are 3 types of enemies:
Fighter (mid-sized) - these are the most common. It takes 3 hits to deactivate it, and it fires projectiles at an average rate. Once attached to your ship, it can be destroyed in one shot.
Cruiser (wide) - these, less common than Fighters, are slightly faster and take 4 hits before they deactivate. Their rate of fire is slower, but their width provides greater cover while attached, and they take 2 shots to destroy once attached to you.
Needle (thin) - as common as Cruisers, Needles are the fastest ship, both in movement speed and rate of fire. However, they also take only one hit to destroy, both when attached to your ship and when active. Because of their small side, they provide limited cover when attached. However, their constant barrage of bullets makes up for it.

entries.title: Man Cannon
entries.description:
A little tank game that I assembled in 10 hours.

Run over enemy soldiers to load them into your tank's cannon. Shoot them to repel the invading forces!

Inspired by: Battle City, Xoldiers, Smash TV, and, apparantly, Bolo.

entries.title: Man Sucks And Blows
entries.description:
Well, this was a total failure.
Let me tally the ways.

Friday, August 20th, 2010
Had to work late, and an electrical storm kicked out my internet. I had no way to see what the friggin' theme was, but I was tired anyway and had to be at work the next morning for another 12 hour shift.

Saturday, August 21st, 2010
Got home super late, still no internet. Luckily I checked the theme while at work, so I had an idea of what I wanted to do. But being this far behind was depressing... and knowing that I couldn't update my LD progress and participate with the rest of the community... or possibly even SUBMIT the game... I didn't have much enthusiasm. Plus I was super tired yet again and only worked on my idea for about an hour.

Sunday, August 22nd, 2010
THE FINAL DAY. STILL NO INTERNET.
So I toiled away for about 4 hours and ended up with a little tech demo and nothing else. 
It's not a game, and I didn't even have time to implement enemies. Only the weapons that were ONCE enemies. This is like seeing the sequel before the prequel. It doesn't translate well.
I still had a chance at the jam, though... so I decided to slap some SFX and music into the game very quickly... with an intent to cram some more programming in on Monday night.

Monday, August 23rd, 2010
HAD TO WORK LATE AGAIN. The internet was finally fixed when I got home, so I spent another hour or so catching up on the LD site and prepping my tech demo for an upload. Didn't have time to add anything new, so I didn't even bother.
And there you have it... my LD 18 time line. OH JOYOUS JOY. I missed it all, and that sucks. I love seeing game previews on Friday and Saturday, then playing the end result on Sunday. It's the best part of Ludum Dare, if you ask me.



MAN SUCKS AND BLOWS
-------------------

Use your enemies as weapons! AWESOME!
Suck up the tiny babies (feature not implemented!) and shoot them (feature IS implemented!) at high velocity towards the face of their evil mother! (feature not implemented!)
Rack up tons of combo points (feature not implemented!) and upgrade your VACUU-GUN (feature not implemented!) to take on the bigger and badder baddies! (feature not implemented!)

Yeah, you get the idea.

You basically run around and shoot little yellow babies in all kinds of directions. That's it.

---------------------------

LEFT AND RIGHT ARROW KEYS - move, man!

UP AND DOWN ARROW KEYS - change the angle, man!

SPACE BAR - shoot out babies, man!

---------------------------

entries.title: Ace Disguise Master
entries.description:
*Was going to have a youtube vid but the recording didn't turn out...*

*Speaking of Bugs if you got my 1.0 version you are invincible! Update now to my 1.1 so you can properly die*

So this game's attempt to follow the theme was to use enemies as weapons by becoming an enemy yourself! So as Ace Disguise Master you defeat enemies and as you do you learn how to disguise as them. When disguised as an enemy you gain their abilities. By the way Ace is so elusive about his identity that he starts the game disguised as a yellow blorber thingy enemy. Can you get through the 6 stages alive? (probably because if you die you restart on the stage you died on. There also seems to be a strange invincibility bug I have yet to resolve)

So the cards are supposed to be your health and what creature you will be next if you get killed. Since I did not get a human interface for all the monsters I made some will just give you a random creature instead

Objective: Get to the yellow door alive! you start at the orange door

Game Features:
3 songs
a bunch of sound effects.
3 different creatures to become disguised as... (was supposed to be 7 didn't get time...)
6 stages
1 ending! Yes the game doesn't randomly exit out on you like my previous one when you beat it.
options to turn off sound (You wouldn't want that right XD. Wait I made the music so maybe you do.)
options to go full screen (Yes I do not force you into full screen at game start)

Controls:
up = jump
left/right = move left and right. (Some times you have to be mid air to move XD )
esc = exit game (sorry was going to make a menu... didn't have time. Well I guess that figures with 48 hours)

Made with Game Maker, Logic Studios, snfx, and Corel
(Wow too bad I don't have Photoshop anymore. Much easier to use than Corel... however I got trained on it first.)

ok well all this typing is making me lazy and you may not be reading this at this point so go ahead and enjoy becoming strange monsters...

entries.title: Mind Control Monster Mash
entries.description:
Giant monsters are attacking your city! Hypnotise them and send them to fight each other. Different monsters are good at beating different other monsters, so you need to choose who you hypnotise strategically.

Made in Flash using ActionScript 3.0

--- HOW TO PLAY ---

Use the mouse to move around the landscape. Use the mouse wheel to zoom in and out.

When you have 100% energy (bar on the left), click on "Mind Control" and click on a monster to hypnotise it. The cursor will change to red rings when you do this.

When a monster is on your side it will change colour.

Click on a monster on your side and the cursor will turn to red. Then click on a square to tell it to go there, or on an enemy monster to tell it to attack it.

Monsters work in a Rock/Paper/Scissors fashion: 
GODZILLA beats TURTLE
TURTLE beats DRAGON
DRAGON beats GODZILLA

When the control centre (centremost building) is destroyed the game ends.

--- NOTES ON JAM VERSION ---

The Jam version is mostly identical, but tidies up the movement to make it less wobbly and more intuitive. It also has more obvious/usable instructions and cursor animations to make it easier to tell how to play.

entries.title: Head Trauma
entries.description:
EDIT: Decided to clarify the links. Also, you're supposed to judge by the "Compo entry" (the MemoryImageSource version is just a little more smooth on FreeBSD just in case you get jerked around by the garbage collector). The "Bonus Jam Entry" does NOT count.

Ah yes, this thing is essentially a half-baked emulation of the Sega Master System.

Pause wasn't implemented.

Do NOT under ANY circumstances play this without sound. It should be illegal.

The second level was just to show multiple levels working - I only made one real level.

Run with:
java -jar HeadTrauma.jar

Z is jump, X is throw.

Use the -nointro switch to skip the splash screen.

The jar has some juicy dev stuff in it, too, feel free to have a nosey around.

NEW: Bonus jam game, Enemies A. S. Weapons, made in ~15 minutes! (I can't enter a separate entry, sorry, so I've tagged it along here. Please don't consider it as part of your compo vote)

entries.title: Infiltrator
entries.description:
Ugh.  Infiltrator is done.

Story:  Two armies have invaded your homeland and laid it to waste: The Red Wolf Army and the Blue Star PMC.  Now that the war is over, your job is infiltrate their combined base and then strike a blow for the people.

How to play:  A simple infiltration game mixed with Robots-style play.  Stay out of the sight cones for the soldiers, unless you intend to lead them to their doom.  Red soldiers will attack blue.  Soldiers can be lead to mines or holes in order to dispatch them, or you can start a firefight between the two groups.

Controls:  Arrow keys.

You can pick up a health pack (red cross) in order to heal yourself.  Mines are small dots that will kill the enemy but not you.  (Mines will insta-kill anything, including tanks.)  Holes will kill you, or an enemy.

Some extra buttons do work:

R - Restart a level (in case FUBAR)
K - Randomly kill an enemy (CHEATING!)
F - FPS counter
SPACEBAR - Skip dialogs (if one is onscreen)

"Music" by Wolfram.

Update: Here is my post-mortem for those interested: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/08/24/ludum-dare-18-entry-infiltrator-post-mortem/

entries.title: Leave Me Alone
entries.description:
Here it is my friends!

This game is called Leave Me Alone; it's about those sad times when life feels overwhelming.

Goal: Entice the things to destroy each other.

Controls:
Arrows = Move.
Space = Restart Level.
X = Start or Continue Game.
-/+/0 = volume/mute.

Please share your thoughts! This is a lonely game, and your thoughts will help me feel less lonely about it.

Coded in AS3 with Flixel. Software used: FlashDevelop, sfxr, Mixcraft, Audacity, Photoshop, Flan.

entries.title: Loputon
entries.description:
Your goal in Loputon is to survive as long as you can and score big combos. As long as there's less than one second between each enemy you kill, your combo counter will rise and you'll score big.

You can defeat the enemies by swinging your bat at them (X), or dashing at them (C). You can only dash once without landing, but whenever you hit an enemy with a dash, you can dash again, so keep chaining enemies to dash around infinitely. Both the bat swing and the dash can be directed with the arrow keys.

The green enemies die instantly, but will make enemies right next to them die due to the small explosion they make. Yellow enemies will fly far back when you hit them, hitting other enemies in the process. Red enemies will explode, killing all nearby enemies.

entries.title: Odd Castle Wars
entries.description: The challenge of the game is around 0, but I still decided to submit it. There are two castles, you control the left one and the lame AI the right one. There are 4 rounds in which you are placing traps and monsters and trying to catch each monsters and destroy each other castle... This is almost my first "full" game so it has lots of bugs and wrong programming.

entries.title: Man And Robot
entries.description:
Retro-styled platformer/puzzle where the main character has the ability to temporarily control the enemy robots. Certain robots have abilities that can be put into use, other times controlling the 'bots is simply to get out of tight squeezes. Be careful when you decide to drop your mine and take over a 'bot because you're completely vulnerable while doing so.. other 'bots might come along and pick you off. Most of the level design was the last two hours, so it's a bit iffy. I'm curious if it's even possible to get through the eight levels. Click where you want to move to, closer the better. Double click to drop the mine in your current location, double click to remove it from anywhere. 

Apparently some people have experienced really slow animation. I cannot account for it, since it runs fine on my 7-year old XP box and my 5-yr old laptop. It won't ever run in Internet Explorer, you guys.. Okay, well, maybe IE9. 

Part of the plan for this game was to do something totally cross-platform with HTML/Javascript, and ideally this sort of thing will run on an iPad or N900. I have only tested it in Firefox, Chrome and Opera and it seems to run well. 
Developed in Linux with GIMP, Gedit, etc. Had to dust off my old WinXP box to run an ancient copy of Reason to do the music (the box of which I'll still need to try out everyone else's stuff!!) Still nothing comparable for Linux yet, but very close. Converted to MP3 && Ogg with Audacity. 

You can download the "Windows version" and play it locally or just simply play it online through the web link. The "source" tarball doesn't include the audio files which makes for a much smaller file. Anyway, have fun. This be my first LD. entries.title: Ol' Conjurer
entries.description:
Fact is it's not finished, it's not close to finished either. Controls are:
WASD to move
E to summon a bunny
Arrow keys to move the bunny
F to attack with the bunny
Q to damage the wizard (debugging for life)
Space to pause the knight so he's not up in your grill

What's in:
> Graphics, sprites and blitting
> Sound, sound manager for all your beeps and boops
> Input, rather necessary
> Ultra basic "AI"

What's not in:
> Title screen
> Collisions
> Damage
> Scoring system
> Swarms of enemies
> Summon upgrades

Essentially, I literally just finished University and have never finished a project, I wasn't sure if I'd finish this or not but I thought what the hell, what have I got to lose by entering. So in my opinion, not a bad effort but that's all it was, an effort, not a game =P ah well, better luck to me next time :)

entries.title: Omnicide
entries.description:
It's sort of an "auto-canabalt" where you grab enemies and throw them to others in order to clear your way.

They can chain-explode, and also they begin using weapons after a while.

When the game starts getting difficult, the only way to survive is to USE ENEMIES AS WEAPONS, making them bounce on the floor for maximum explosions.


It was done in under 9 hours.
Tools/SDKs used:
SFXR, RazorLame, Musagi, FlashDevelop, Flixel, GraphicsGale, Audacity

entries.title: Possessomancer
entries.description: Just a proof-of-concept, really. Needs some better art, some audio, and definitely some gameplay tweaking.

entries.title: Robocolosseum
entries.description:
You have entered the RoboColosseum's greatest challenge: the never-ending cannon swarm so intent on your destruction they fire their own comrades at you, thus your enemies are weapons that are used by other enemies! Armed with nothing but the ability to create walls, you must destroy as many enemy robots as possible. Bonus points apply for acting the destructo-cannonball yourself! Can you beat the high score?

If you do like this game, the graphics look noticeably better in fullscreen and it's easier to figure out what's going on, so please, go ahead and download it :D

The source is essentially the entire unity project folder, with some bonus raw files for art and music - point unity at it and go

entries.title: Takeover
entries.description:
Arrow keys to move, ram a ship as the pod to control it, Z to eject and go back to pod. Whenever you see a new enemy, eject and capture it, pretty much.

Enemy waves are set to loop.
some cool things, but a lot less complete then I'd like.

If you die in a ship, you autoeject. If you die as a pod, you disappear and are unable to move. No Menu / Game Over /stars in the sky. A few bugs and stuff. Try to stay on the screen as I didn't get around to the edge of screen stopping you. I made a fancy laser weapon, but didn't get around to it actually hurting you so figured I'd leave it out.

100% code, bitmaps are for cheaters. Made with Flashdevelop.
